classberg.heading: ClassBerg
story: When I was preparing for the MHT-CET, which is an engineering entrance exam, I was studying independently. I was looking for platforms where I could practice for the exam and get some feedback about my perfomance. However, all of the platforms I found were either inadequate or very costly.

So I decided to create a community-driven platform which would give students practice, performance analytics, and much more, and would moreover be free for students. The idea was that I would sell coaching classes access to the platform as a subscription, and that would help keep the platform free for independent students.

I worked on the website for around 9 months, after which I approached my old coaching class. I conducted extensive beta-testing with their teachers and students, and got some important feedback that I incorporated into the website. I also sold them a customized installation of the website on their internal network.

Following this, I approached the technology incubator at the College of Engineering, Pune, and presented my idea to them. They agreed to incubate my platform, and I worked with them for the next few months.
description: ClassBerg was meant to be a SaaS which provided Indian coaching classes with a student testing framework, virtual classrooms, and a question database.
ClassBerg is now a freelance project which I customize as per individual classes' requirements and provision servers for on their behalf, usually using Heroku and AWS.
Classberg.com was selected for incubation by College of Engineering, Pune's technology incubator.

classberg-exed.heading: ClassBerg x EXED IIT
story: After working on ClassBerg for around 9 months, I approached my old tuition class and pitched my platform to them. They liked the idea and wanted to use it for internal student testing.

For the next 4 months, I worked with them, conducted beta testing, and received feedback about all aspects of the software. I identified two significant shortcomings for which I had to design my own solutions, which resulted in two open-source libraries - MJXGUI and docxlatex.

The first shortcoming was that being an engineering class, they frequently needed to insert mathematical and chemical equations into their questions, but there was no easy way to do so in a web form. I searched for solutions, but I couldn't find any that fit my use case and requirements. So I developed MJXGUI, which solved precisely that problem.

The second shortcoming was that they already had a considerable collection of question banks and tests stored as Microsoft Word (.docx) files, and they wanted to be able to use those files directly to create tests on the platform. The existing .docx parsers for python didn't support extraction of mathematical equations, so I created docxlatex.
After working with them, gathering feedback, and incorporating it iteratively, I sold them a customized installation on their local network for personal use.
description: A customized installation of ClassBerg's source code for EXED IIT's domain, with features including student attendance tracking, assignment creation and submission, and test creation from uploaded .docx files using docxlatex.
Designed specifically for serving low traffic with low compute power servers.

chessengine.heading: Chess Engine
description: A python implementation of a chess engine with no dependencies.
Features a bitboard representation and API, move generation API, PGN parsing support, and alpha-beta pruned search with move ordering.

docxlatex.heading: docxlatex
description: docxlatex is a python module for extracting text from .docx files, including support for mathematical and chemical equations, primarily for use with tools like MathJax.
It also includes support for extracting images and conversion of extracted equations into LaTeX syntax.

mjxgui.heading: MJXGUI
description: MJXGUI is an equation editor for the web for building mathematical and chemical equations with a GUI similar to Google Docs or Microsoft Word. It supports conversion of the entered equations into LaTeX for storage and rendering using tools like MathJax.
Try the demo below to create an equation.
mobile-hide
MJXGUI does not support all of its features on mobile devices.
message-warning
mobile-element

lifenotes.heading: LifeNotes
description: LifeNotes is a timeline web app that allows you to create interactive, shareable timelines in the browser.
You can tag notes and search and filter between different tags to find notes faster.
It uses vis-timeline as the timeline renderer, and shows you a responsive, interactive horizontal timeline.
The LifeNotes timeline works best on devices with bigger screens
message-warning-dark

otshare.heading: OTShare
description: OTShare allows you to send data securely from a public computer to your devices, or for other users to send you anonymous messages
It uses one time passwords to eliminate the need for you to log into any service, but at the same time allows you to control who can send you messages.

chainrxn.heading: chainrxn
description: A browser-based implementation of the popular game "Chain Reaction" by Buddy-Matt Entertainment that lets users play on their own devices
